lines.content: This is a project for a greenfield Java chatbot project,
based on Duke, the National University of Singapore (NUS)'s
It's named after the term _Yapper_, which is a slang term for someone who talks too much (without much meaningful content).
Given below are instructions on how to use it.
Prerequisites: JDK 17, update Intellij to the most recent version.
1. Open Intellij (if you are not in the welcome screen, click `File` > `Close Project` to close the existing project first)
2. Open the project into Intellij as follows:
2. Select the project directory, and click `OK`.
3. If there are any further prompts, accept the defaults.
3. Configure the project to use **JDK 17** (not other versions) as explained in [here](https://www.jetbrains.com/help/idea/sdk.html#set-up-jdk).
In the same dialog, set the **Project language level** field to the `SDK default` option.
4. After that, locate the `src/main/java/yapper/Yapper.java` file, right-click it, and choose `Run Yapper.main()`
(if the code editor is showing compile errors, try restarting the IDE). If the setup is correct, you should see something like the below as the output:
Ya ready for me to yap yer ear off?
To jog your memory, here's what we can discuss:
list, if you forgot what you said.
bye, if you want me to stop yappin.
delete [index], if you don't want something.
mark [index], if you're done with something.
unmark [index], if you're not done with something.
find [keyword], if you're looking for something.
todo [todoDesc], to for a task with no dates.
deadline [deadlineDesc] /by [end], for a task with an end date.
event [eventDesc] /from [start] /to [end], for a task with a start date and an end date.
The code above should appear so long as you don't have a `savefile.txt` in a `data` folder,
in which case another message will be shown instead.
This project is a fork of the Duke project template, found
guide to set up and get started.
The **architecture** diagram given above explains the high-level design of Yapper.
Given below is a quick overview of main components and how they interact with each other
1. **Yapper class**: The entry point of the program, managing the core loop and coordinating other components.
2. **instructions package**: Handles user input parsing and command processing.
3. **tasks package**: Handles tasks, including their types and related operations (ToDo, Deadline, Event).
4. **io package**: Handles input/output operations, including reading and writing tasks to/from files.
5. **exceptions package**: Handles custom exceptions for application-specific errors.
The sections below give more details of each component.
The `Yapper` class is the main entry point of the program.
It manages the program's main loop, parses and processes user input,
and also handles program initialization and termination.
1. main checks for an existing save file via `InputFileHandler`.
2. If absent, it initializes an empty `TaskHandler`, then prints the startup and help message.
If present, it loads the file's contents into `TaskHandler`, then prints a different message.
3. After that, it starts the chatbot loop.
4. When the loop is exited, it displays a shutdown message.
1. Within a loop, user input is read from the command line via `Scanner`,
user input is parsed and validated via `InputStringHandler`, then
2. The loop continues indefinitely until a valid bye command is entered.
If input is an invalid bye command, it outputs a warning message.
This package contains classes used for handling and parsing user input.
The `Instruction` class represents a command issued by the user.
It contains the parsed command type (e.g. add, delete) and its associated arguments.
The `InstructionHandler` class is responsible for executing user commands.
It interprets `Instruction` objects, invoking the appropriate methods to perform actions like adding or deleting tasks.
This package handles the logic for task management, including different types of tasks and their operations.
The `TaskHandler` class manages the list of tasks.
It provides methods to add, remove, and retrieve tasks,
as well as converting tasks to and from a string format for file storage.
The `Task` class is an abstract base class representing a generic task.
It includes properties such as the task description and completion status.
All task types (ToDo, Deadline, Event) inherit from this class.
The `Todo` class extends `Task` and represents a simple task with no specific date or time constraints.
The `Deadline` class extends `Task` and represents a task that has a due date, with only a end time.
The `Event` class extends `Task` and represents a task occurring at a specific time, with both start and end times.
This package manages input and output, including file storage and handling user input/output.
The `InputStringHandler` class processes and validates raw user input,
converting it into commands that the `InstructionHandler` can interpret.
The `OutputStringHandler` class formats output strings for the user.
It prepares well-structured responses and error messages for display.
The `InputFileHandler` class is responsible for reading task data from text files.
It loads saved tasks at program start and parses them back into task objects.
The `OutputFileHandler` class writes tasks to a text file for persistent storage.
It converts task objects into a savable string format and updates the file during runtime.
The `StringStorage` class contains predefined strings used across the program for consistency,
including responses, prompts, and error messages.
The `DateAndTimeHandler` class is responsible for handling date and time parsing and formatting.
It converts user input dates into a standard format for `Deadline` and `Event` tasks.
This package contains exception-related classes to handle errors specific to Yapper.
The `YapperException` class is a custom exception used to represent Yapper-specific errors,
such as invalid commands or missing arguments.
The `ExceptionHandler` class processes exceptions that occur during runtime, with user-friendly error messages.
**Yapper** is a CLI-based (Command Line Interface) ChatBot that
helps you manage tasks such as ToDos, Deadlines and Events,
When you first run Yapper, you will be greeted with a start-up message, and a help message:
Ya ready for me to yap yer ear off?
To jog your memory, here's what we can discuss:
list, if you forgot what you said.
help, if you forgot what kinda stuff we can yap about.
bye, if you want me to stop yappin.
delete [index], if you don't want something.
mark [index], if you're done with something.
unmark [index], if you're not done with something.
find [keyword], if you're looking for something.
todo [todoDesc], to for a task with no dates.
deadline [deadlineDesc] /by [end], for a task with an end date.
event [eventDesc] /from [start] /to [end], for a task with a start date and an end date.
You can then start entering commands to add tasks, and more.
Yapper will only understand user inputs that start with the keywords above.
use the command keyword, followed by additional arguments if any,
e.g. `Shown here is how to format your input so that Yapper understands`.
Shown here is a sample program output based on the sample input above.
The command keyword is always in lowercase.
use the todo command followed by the task description
Now, I gotta remember this too:
If I counted correctly, you have a task total of 1
Don't worry, I've already memorized all about it!
use the deadline command followed by the task description then an end date,
Now, I gotta remember this too:
If I counted correctly, you have a task total of 2
Don't worry, I've already memorized all about it!
use the event command followed by the event description, a start date then an end date,
Now, I gotta remember this too:
If I counted correctly, you have a task total of 3
Don't worry, I've already memorized all about it!
To delete a (ToDo, Deadline or Event) task,
use the delete command followed by the task number,
Now I don't need to remember this one anymore:
If I counted correctly, you have a task total of 0
Don't worry, I've already forgotten about it!
To list all tasks in your task list,
use the list command without any parameters.
You're forgetting already? Lemme refresh your memory:
That should be all of them. Did I forget any?
use the find command followed by the query string,
This will list all tasks which have that query in its description, if any.
Hmmm, let me think. What tasks could you be referring to?
2 task(s) found contains your query string.
Is any of them what you were looking for?
To mark a task as complete,
use the mark command followed by the task number,
I know, you told me that this task is done
Keep it up! What are you gonna do next?
To unmark a task as incomplete,
use the unmark command followed by the task number,
I know, you told me that this task is not done
Keep going, you'll get it done eventually!
use the help command without any parameters,
To jog your memory, here's what we can discuss:
list, if you forgot what you said.
help, if you forgot what kinda stuff we can yap about.
bye, if you want me to stop yappin.
delete [index], if you don't want something.
mark [index], if you're done with something.
unmark [index], if you're not done with something.
find [keyword], if you're looking for something.
todo [todoDesc], to for a task with no dates.
deadline [deadlineDesc] /by [end], for a task with an end date.
event [eventDesc] /from [start] /to [end], for a task with a start date and an end date.
use the bye command without any parameters,
Thanks for listenin' to my yappin'.
Call for me whenever ya feel like listening again.
If a command requires additional parameters, they must be included and must be in the same order indicated.
If a command does not require additional parameters, do not include anything after the command keyword.
Command keywords are always in lowercase.
| todo     | Adds a new Todo task to the list                                 | todo [desc]                          | todo study for exam                        |
| deadline | Adds a new Deadline task to the list                             | deadline [desc] /by [date]           | deadline canvas quiz /by today             |
| event    | Adds a new Event task to the list                                | event [desc] /from [date] /to [date] | event tP meeting /from today 2000 /to 2100 |
| delete   | Deletes a task from the list                                     | delete [ordinal]                     | delete 6                                   |
| mark     | Marks an uncompleted task in the list as done                    | mark  [ordinal]                      | mark 4                                     |
| unmark   | Marks a completed task in the list as not done                   | unmark [ordinal]                     | unmark 3                                   |
| list     | Lists all tasks in the list                                      | list                                 | list                                       |
| find     | Lists all tasks in the list whose description contains the query | find [query]                         | find CS2113                                |
| bye      | Exits the program with a goodbye message                         | bye                                  | bye                                        |
Do note that parameters must be of a certain type:
The task list is saved in a file, savedata.txt, located in the data folder.
This file is updated in real-time, i.e. it updates every time you
add (todo, deadline, event), remove, or update (mark/unmark) the list.
When Yapper boots up, it searches for that file and converts its contents into a task list.
However, it can only convert text in a particular format, so edit the file with caution.
Don't worry if you accidentally deleted your save file or the folder that it is in.
The next time you update the task list in the terminal, Yapper will create a new file (and its folder, if necessary) and fill the file in with the tasks it has.
Unless you delete the save file and end the program without saying anything to Yapper,
in which case your tasks are gone forever.
* The Yapper class implements a simple command-line chatbot.
* It interacts with the user through a loop that
* processes user input, handles tasks, and manages program flow.
* Validates the existence of the save folder and file.
* If either the folder or the file does not exist, they are created.
* After creating or validating their existence, the tasks managed by the

* @throws IOException if an I/O error occurs during file or folder initialization.
* @throws YapperException if a Yapper-specific error occurs during task storage.
* Starts the main chatbot loop, allowing the user to interact
* with the chatbot until they decide to exit.
* @param taskHandler the TaskHandler instance that manages tasks
* The main method that serves as the entry point of the Yapper program.
* It initializes the TaskHandler, starts the chatbot loop,
* and displays messages when the program starts and ends.
* The {@code ExceptionHandler} class provides methods for validating user input and
* handling exceptions related to task management in the Yapper chatbot application.
* It throws {@code YapperException} with appropriate messages if any checks below fail:

* HELP, FIND, LIST, TODO, DEADLINE, EVENT, DELETE, MARK, UNMARK
* Enumeration of the types of instructions supported by Yapper.
* FIND: Show tasks that contains the query. <li/>
* MARK: Mark a task as complete. <li/>

* It is used in all instruction types.

* For EVENT tasks, it contains two dates (start and end date).
* The description of the task associated with the instruction.
* It is used in all instruction types.

* It is used in these instruction types:

* A utility class for handling date and time formatting and parsing in Yapper.
* This class provides predefined format patterns for displaying and storing dates and times,
* as well as a method to format dates based on user input or internal representation.
* Date and time format patterns for display purposes.
public static final String DATE_WITH_TIME_TO_DISPLAY = "MM/dd/yyyy, EEE, hh:mm a";
* Date and time format patterns for converting to string, for storage purposes.
public static final String DATE_WITH_TIME_TO_STRING = "yyyy-dd-MM hhmm";
* Date and time format patterns for parsing input from the user.
public static final String DATE_WITH_TIME_INPUT = "yyyy-MM-dd HHmm";
* Returns the formatted date or datetime string based on the input parameters.
* If the provided {@code dateString} is not empty, it is returned as is.
* Otherwise, it formats either the {@code dateWithoutTime} or {@code dateWithTime}
* based on the provided format patterns.
* @param dateString    The original date string. If not empty, this will be returned.
* @param dateWithoutTime A {@link LocalDate} instance, used if no time is provided.
* @param dateWithTime  A {@link LocalDateTime} instance, used if time is provided.
* @param dateOnly      The format pattern to use if only the date is provided.
* @param dateAndTime   The format pattern to use if both date and time are provided.
* @return The formatted date or datetime string.
String dateString, LocalDate dateWithoutTime, LocalDateTime dateWithTime,

* Contains characters/strings for the Yapper program
* The {@code StringStorage} class holds various constants and utility methods
* related to string management for user input and output.
* Constants in this class are organized into several categories: <ul>

*
  • File Management: Constants related to file paths and delimiters.

*
  • User Instructions: Constants representing prefixes for user commands.

*
  • Task Symbols: Symbols used to represent task types and statuses.

*
  • Exception Messages: Messages used to inform users of issues or missing input.
* An offset value used to adjust indexing for user input and display.
* Thus, the user input ordinal = internal use ordinal + this offset value.
* Constants representing prefixes for user commands, for User I/O.
* Symbols used to represent task types and statuses, for File I/O.
* Divides text printed to output, to distinguish between different sets of messages
* Messages that occur when no instruction can be executed.
* They come either when user cannot input instructions,
* or are meant to be exhaustive.
* Hence they can afford to be more wordy.
"To jog your memory, here's what we can discuss: \n"
+ "list" + ", if you forgot what you said. \n"
+ "help" + ", if you forgot what kinda stuff we can yap about. \n"
+ "bye" + ", if you want me to stop yappin. \n"
+ "unmark [index]" + ", if you're not done with something. \n"
+ "todo [todoDesc]" + ", to for a task with no dates. \n"
+ "deadline [deadlineDesc] /by [end]" + ", for a task with an end date. \n"
+ "event [eventDesc] /from [start] /to [end]" + ", for a task with a start date and an end date. ";
+ "Ya ready for me to yap yer ear off? \n"
"Let us resume where we left off, shall we? ";
+ "Call for me whenever ya feel like listening again. \n"
* Messages that occur when instructions are being executed.
* They are a small component of the program output,
* coming before, after or between printing of tasks.
"Hmmm, let me think. What tasks could you be referring to? ";
" task(s) found contains your query string. \n"
+ "Is any of them what you were looking for? ";
"No tasks found that contains your query string. \n"
+ "Sorry, I don't recall anything that is related to that. ";
"You're forgetting already? Lemme refresh your memory: ";
"That should be all of them. Did I forget any? ";
"Don't worry, I've already memorized all about it! ";
"Now I don't need to remember this one anymore: ";
"Don't worry, I've already forgotten about it! ";
"If I counted correctly, you have a task total of ";
"I know, you told me that this task is ";
"Keep it up! What are you gonna do next? ";
"Keep going, you'll get it done eventually! ";
* Messages that may occur when exceptions are detected during user input parsing.
* Only one will occur for any single line the user inputs,
* so no likelihood of flooding the user with messages.
* Hence they can afford to be more wordy.
+ "I can say nothing in reply. I just stare at you. \n"
+ "There is an awkward silence between us.";
+ "I need more details to understand what you wanna do. ";
"Input does not start with any of the known prefixes: "
+ "Explain in a way I can understand. ";
+ "Sorry, I didn't catch what you just said. Repeat it for me will ya? ";
* Messages that may occur when exceptions are detected after user input parsing.
* Only one will occur for any single line the user inputs,
* so no likelihood of flooding the user with messages.
* Hence they can afford to be more wordy.
+ "You have nothing to remember at the moment. ";
+ "I don't what you're referring to. Come again? ";
+ "I know you've already done this. No need to tell me again. ";
"Task is already marked as not done. \n"
+ "I know you still haven't done this. I won't forget. ";
* Messages that may occur when exceptions are detected during file input parsing.
* Each will be printed per exception detected,
* so groups of them may flood the user with messages.
"task description not given. "; // "You haven't told me what this is for. ";
"Start date is not given. "; // "You haven't told me when this starts. ";
"End date is not given. "; // "You haven't told me when this ends. ";
"Task type abbreviation is not any of these: "
+ SYMBOL_EVENT; // "I don't remember if what kind of task this is.";
"Task completion status abbreviation is not any of these: "
+ SYMBOL_NOT_DONE; // "I don't remember if this task was done or not.";
